Overview.Summary: In 2024, Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko announced his intention to seek re-election, potentially extending his 30-year rule (1). The Central Election Commission registered the elected members of the Council of Republic (3). Polls opened for parliamentary and local elections (6). The elections were scheduled for March 17th (8) and candidates for the Council of the Republic were nominated in March, with the elections taking place in April (9). The chair of the Belarusian People's Congress, deputy chair, and Presidium will be chosen by delegates in April (10).

Timeline.Text: Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko announces his intention to seek re-election next year.
The Central Election Commission registers the elected members of the Council of the Republic.

Overview.Summary: The 2024 Belarusian parliamentary election will take place on an unspecified date in the future, as there is no information about the specific date in the given articles. However, it is known that current president Alexander Lukashenko intends to seek re-election (1, 10). The election has not yet been scheduled, but the timetable for general elections in the UK is 25 working days (9). Belarusian authorities have refused to invite observers from the OSCE to monitor the election (6). The election could potentially have implications for the wider world (4).

Timeline.Text: Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko announces he will seek re-election next year.
Mozambique holds parliamentary elections, with FRELIMO expected to dominate.
The People's National Congress, a pro-China party, wins 70 out of 93 seats in the Maldives parliamentary elections.
A presidential election in 2024 with profound implications for the wider world takes place.
Bhutan's People's Democratic Party wins the parliamentary election.
Belarus refuses to invite OSCE observers to monitor parliamentary and local elections.
Taiwanese voters elect a new legislature, costing the Democratic Progressive Party its absolute majority.
Belarus adopts a new military doctrine that involves nuclear weapons.
The timetable for a general election in the UK is set to 25 working days.
Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko gives himself immunity from prosecution and limits on his powers.

Overview.Summary: Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko plans to seek re-election in 2024 (1). Overview.Summary: Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko announced his intention to seek re-election in the 2024 parliamentary election (1,2,3,4). The election, which was held on February 25, was decried as a sham by the opposition (6). Lukashenko further consolidated his control by signing a new law giving himself lifelong immunity from prosecution and preventing opposition leaders living abroad from running in future elections (12,13,14). The Belarusian government also refused to invite observers from the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE) to monitor the election (6,7,8,9,10). However, international observers were invited from other organizations, such as the CIS election observation mission (17). The election campaign period began on January 31 and will end on February 24 (18). In addition to the parliamentary election, Belarus also signed a cooperation roadmap with Russia for 2024-2026 (16).

Timeline.Text: Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko announces his intention to seek re-election next year, potentially extending his grip on the country to 36 years.
President Lukashenko signs a new law giving himself lifelong immunity from criminal prosecution and preventing opposition leaders living abroad from running in future presidential elections.
In a New Year's charity event, President Lukashenko tightens his control over the country's opposition.
Belarusian government television broadcasts an interview with opposition member Tatiana Kurilina, causing controversy.
Belarusian authorities announce they will not invite observers from the OSCE to monitor the country's parliamentary and local elections.
Belarusian authorities snub OSCE election observers, tightening President Lukashenko's authoritarian control.
Belarus's President Lukashenko hints at a new doctrine for using nuclear weapons.
International observers are invited to monitor Belarus's 2024 elections.
After a failed mutiny in 2023, mercenaries from the Wagner Group are reportedly still in Belarus.
Belarus and Russia sign a cooperation roadmap for 2024-2026.
The election campaign period for Belarus's single voting day begins.
As Belarus votes in tightly controlled elections, its leader accuses the West of fueling unrest.
